channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Care services investigating too many families - review
item.description: Child protection services in England are not providing enough early support, a report says.

item.title: Covid: Epidemic growing across England, says study
item.description: The rollout of jabs to younger people is key to reducing further spread, researchers say.

item.title: Covid: Ryanair and Manchester Airports Group take legal action over travel traffic light system
item.description: There is anger in the travel sector over how the government has made decisions over the green list.

item.title: NI first and deputy first minister nominations expected
item.description: The DUP and Sinn Féin are expected to make the move as a stalemate over Irish language laws is resolved.

item.title: UK aid cuts risk millions of lives, warns World Health Organization
item.description: It leaves millions of the world’s poorest at risk from “neglected tropical diseases”, says agency.

item.title: Shenzhou-12: China launches first crew to new space station
item.description: Three astronauts successfully take off for China's longest ever human spaceflight mission.

item.title: Robyn Williams: Sacked Met officer wins appeal against dismissal
item.description: Robyn Williams was sacked after a 36-year career for having a child abuse video on her phone.

item.title: Kim Jong-un admits to 'tense' food situation in North Korea
item.description: He told the ruling party that the coronavirus pandemic and a series of storms had led to bad harvests.

item.title: Biden and Putin praise Geneva summit talks but discord remains
item.description: The US and Russia agree to nuclear arms control talks but progress at the Geneva summit is limited.

item.title: Apple Daily: Hong Kong sends 500 officers in pro-democracy paper raid
item.description: The editor-in-chief and four other executives of the paper were also arrested on Thursday morning.

item.title: MPs vote for a four-week delay to England's lockdown easing
item.description: Lockdown restrictions can stay in place until 19 July rather than 21 June, despite a Tory rebellion.

item.title: Thousandth dormouse brought back to the wild
item.description: The captive-bred hazel dormouse is now settling into its new woodland home in Lancashire.

item.title: The Papers: 'Nuclear Dom' and return of holidays for vaccinated
item.description: The latest twist in the war of words between Dominic Cummings and Matt Hancock features on the front pages.

item.title: When Biden met Putin: Decoding the world leaders' body language
item.description: A body language expert unpacks the postures and gestures of the two world leaders at their summit.

item.title: Covid causes new environmental dilemma for India’s Ganges River
item.description: Hundreds of bodies have been buried in shallow graves along the banks of the already-polluted Ganges.

item.title: Tom McClean: The man who still dreams of crossing Atlantic in a whale
item.description: Adventurer Tom McClean, 78, has never given up on his ambition to make the voyage in his whale-shaped boat Moby.

item.title: Botswana diamond could be world's third largest
item.description: The "rare and extraordinary" gem weighs 1,098 carats and was unveiled by diamond firm, Debswana.

item.title: Peruvians reweave Incan 'living bridge' over river
item.description: Communities literally came together to recreate the historic rope bridge, meeting in the middle.

item.title: Bigfoot: How the Primal Scream-headlined music festival is going ahead
item.description: Bigfoot will see performances by Primal Scream and Hot Chip despite current lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Love Island: ITV announces new contestant welfare measures
item.description: Participants on the show's seventh series will also receive "comprehensive" psychological support.

item.title: Living with obesity: 'My genes mean I’m hard-wired to store fat'
item.description: Specialist health professionals say obesity should be regarded as a complex illness, and people with the condition shouldn't be blamed for it.

item.title: Manchester Arena Inquiry: ‘Unforgivable' security mistakes
item.description: A man who lost his partner in the 2017 Manchester attack says failings made it "easy" for the bomber.

item.title: Delta variant: Fact-checking claims about Covid and borders
item.description: Claims about whether the UK border policy contributed to the spread of the Delta Covid variant dominated Prime Minister's Questions.

item.title: Australia's growing thirst for alcohol-free wine and beer
item.description: Demand for non-alcoholic drinks "explodes" as more Australians rethink their drinking habits.

item.title: Iran's presidential election: Four claims fact-checked
item.description: TV debate topics included censorship, Iran's economic performance and political prisoners.

item.title: Why the cruise industry is still navigating choppy waters
item.description: The global cruise line industry is hoping to now recover from the pandemic, but problems remain.

item.title: 'I'll work 100-hour weeks to clear our Covid debt'
item.description: Businesses have run up an "unprecedented" amount of debt in the pandemic, say industry groups.

item.title: 'Wales' stars sparkled once more' - how Bale & Ramsey inspired Wales to within touching distance of last 16
item.description: Gareth Bale and Aaron Ramsey rediscover their star quality to inspire Wales' 2-0 win over Turkey and take a major step towards the last 16 of Euro 2020.

item.title: England skipper Knight hits 95 but India fight back on absorbing first day - highlights & report
item.description: England suffer a late collapse against India after a sterling 95 from captain Heather Knight on a fluctuating first day of the one-off Test.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'A winning machine' - but just how far can Italy go?
item.description: Italy make a statement as Roberto Mancini's side become the first team to qualify for the last 16 but should their form at the Euros really come as a surprise?

item.title: I'm fit to face Scotland, says England defender Maguire
item.description: Defender Harry Maguire says he is fit and available for England's second Euro 2020 Group D match against Scotland at Wembley on Friday.

item.title: Norrie to face fellow Briton Draper in Queen's quarter-finals - video & report
item.description: British number two Cameron Norrie will face teenage compatriot Jack Draper in the Queen's quarter-finals after both win on Wednesday.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'Magnificent from Wales' - Goals and best fan park reaction from Wales' famous win
item.description: All the action, celebrations and reaction from Wales' 2-0 victory over Turkey in Baku as they take a huge step towards qualification for the last 16 of the European Championships.

item.title: England v India: Captain Heather Knight hits 95 but India fight back - highlights
item.description: A stellar effort from captain Heather Knight and a late collapse from England provide an intriguing end to day one of their one-off Test against India at Bristol.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government has said some restrictions will stay in place in England after 21 June.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 42 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions in England has been delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: 'We want another homeless hotel - and we can make it work'
item.description: The Holiday Inn in Gorton, Manchester, housed homeless people throughout the pandemic, until the end of May.

item.title: 'Huntington's disease won't stop me having a baby'
item.description: Heather and her husband are going to have a baby, even though Heather's time with the child will be limited.

item.title: 'The 80s song that brought my lost memory back after 10 years'
item.description: A car crash erased Thomas's memory - 10 years later, a 1980s pop song triggered six flashbacks.

item.title: Myanmar: The mysterious deaths of the NLD party officials
item.description: The deaths of officials from Aung San Suu Kyi's party have raised scrutiny of the military's actions.

item.title: Freddie Figgers: The millionaire tech inventor who was 'thrown away' as a baby
item.description: Entrepreneur Freddie Figgers says life has taught him that the important thing is people, not profits.
